column2: pronounced [pʰí(ʔ).t͡ɕìt]) is one of Thailand's seventy-six provinces (changwat) lies in lower northern Thailand and 330 km due north of Bangkok. Neighbouring provinces are (from north clockwise) Phitsanulok

column1: The Nan and Yom Rivers flow through Phichit Province
column2: joining shortly before the Chao Phraya is formed. The province mainly consists of low fertile river plains
column3: making rice and lotus the main crops.

column1: The town of Phichit was established in 1058 by Phraya Kotabongthevaraja (พระยาโคตระบอง)
column2: and was first part of the Sukhothai Kingdom
column3: and later of Ayutthaya. An old temple in Pho Prathap Chang District is Wat Pho Prathap Chang (วัดโพธิ์ประทับช้าง). It was built by Phra Chao Suea
column5: in 1701 at a site reputed to be his birthplace. The site is surrounded by double-walls and huge trees
column6: some of which are over 200 years old.The name of the main city changed several times. At first it was called Sa Luang ('city of the royal pond'). In Ayutthaya times it was called Okhaburi ('city in the swamp')

column1: The provincial seal shows a pond
column2: which refers to the old name of Phichit
column3: Mueang Sa Luang ("city of the royal pond"). The banyan tree in front refers to Wat Pho Prathap Chang. The temple was built in 1669-1671 by King Luang Sorasak
column4: who was born in the village of Pho Prathap Chang
column5: between a banyan and a sacred fig.

column1: The flag of Phichit shows the circular provincial seal in the middle. It has three green bars and two white horizontal bars
column2: with the middle bar being interrupted by the seal.

column1: The provincial tree is the ironwood. The provincial flower is the lotus.
The provincial motto (loosely translated) states as follows:
The province of Chalawan the crocodile king
column2: the fun and exciting annual boat race
column3: the land of exquisite rice and the delicious Tha Khoi pomelo; the center of the province is the Luang Pho Phet.

column1: The main hospital in Phichit is Phichit Hospital
column2: operated by the Ministry of Public Health.

column1: Phichit main station is Phichit Railway Station.
The province is divided into 12 districts (amphoes). These are further divided into 89 subdistricts (tambons) and 852 villages (mubans).
As of 26 November 2019 there are: one Phichit Provincial Administration Organisation (ongkan borihan suan changwat) and 28 municipal (thesaban) areas in the province. Phichit
column2: Taphan Hin and Bang Mun Nak have town (thesaban mueang) status. Further 25 subdistrict municipalities (thesaban tambon). The non-municipal areas are administered by 73 Subdistrict Administrative Organisations - SAO (ongkan borihan suan tambon).
United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) in Thailand has tracked progress on human development at sub-national level using the Human achievement index (HAI)
column3: a composite index covering all the eight key areas of human development. National Economic and Social Development Board (NESDB) has taken over this task since 2017.

column1: Den Junlaphan a.k.a. Eagle Kyowa: professional boxer
